WHY is downward dog so difficult!!!

I am not a yoga teacher but I do care a great deal about mobility. If it is extra difficult and you feel a deep stretch in the  heel cords and or hamstrings, you could get a lacrosse ball, sit on it  and smash out the restricted tissues in the booty and the hamstrings working down to the heel cord and calf area for about 10-15 minutes before your yoga practice, this helps to feed slack into the tissues (it hurts like crazy but you learn to yoga breathe and deal). Once the tissues are less restricted you can sink deeper into this pose, and once there chill out in a heel cord stretch pose like down dog  for about 8 min to cause real long lasting tissue change. The science supports 8 mins a KEY Doing this Physical Therapy practice has led me to label it Super Yoga as it allowed me to make tremendous gains in a relatively short time. Hope that helps.

Hi Cserei! In general, most women are able to continue a regular practice through month eight if they avoid twists below the neck, core activation and anything on the belly. Most will find they will know when something isn't right. Hip openers are good but go easier in third trimester. Modify core breaks with reclined cobbler's pose, modify belly stuff with child's pose or yogi's squat and modify standing twists with wide-legged forward fold. As always, consult your doctor/physician before starting and follow their advice. xx

To the more experienced Yogi's; I am finding myself drifting off and not staying present when I do the practice at night. Any advice?
@Swandi this is SUPER helpful, thank you!!

I would call myself a middle experienced Yogi, but I know your problem well. A lot of reason could lead to not being present in the pratice, so I will just list some ideas of what may help and with what you can expiriment:
1. Is it maybe not the "right" time for you. Maybe try different times, if possible and see what difference they make for you.
2. The breath. I took me some time to get it and to get to know myself better. When I drift off know in the practice, I try to concentrate more on the breath, then on what my body has to do (does not always work, but helps). This needs practice, I think, at some days it will work awesome and others my head just runs away.
3. Take your time before the practice to really be present. Maybe pause the video at the beginning at just take more time to arrive. Don't judge yourself at days were you need more time, it is part of yoga to aknowladge how you feel.

And the most importent thing, I think is: at some days my mind just is not present and sometimes I'm not able to change that. I still do the practice than, even tho it doesn't feel as good as when I'm really present. But that's sometimes how it is, like a bad day. At least I can be proud, that I did my pracitce, something for my mind and body. So listen to yourself (sounds so easy, is so damn hard) , find out what helps and don't go to hard on yourself, if it doesn't work sometimes.

Hope some of this helps!

Today, I approached getting on the mat as a "checklist" item, anticipating a lackluster practice, because I felt like I'd gotten the day off on the wrong foot by waking up late. I did run before practice, so my muscles were warmed up, and actually, it all flowed incredibly well. I connected to my breath and my pigeon was on point, so I just put some attention on the fact that I had come to the mat with some ickiness.


aaaand I'm about go FULL DEAR DIARY up in here, I can feel it coming - but I'll take the theme of inquiry as an invitation to feelings vom everywhere :)



some of what I came to the mat with -- after I rode the "SHINY NEW DECADE!" energy into an auspicious beginning for 2020, I've been slipping into some old habits...and it's only been a week! of course, the place to strive for is self-forgiveness -- but perhaps I was jumping there too quickly, without also acknowledging the (quote-unquote) negative emotions of disappointment and letting them exist. so that disappointment/ickiness ends up getting projected on to other areas (i.e. YWA) that I'm subconsciously associating with transformation. (i.e. "what is even the POINT, i shall forever languish as a useless BLOB")
and of course, with inquiry, we can choose to see our experience with curiosity. in regards to some of the "old" habits (a sticky, interconnected web of ego stories about procrastination, internet browsing/surfing + phone use, being a Productive and Useful Member of Society) -- yes, I don't want to be manipulated by the endless dopamine quest, but also, I did have the thought that maybe it can also be a signal that I'm seeking connection in my life. I'm quite independent, but I was traveling a lot for the first half of 2019, then resettled into a new city, where I'm still getting on my feet, and...just. it's okay to feel some type of way.

sigh. wherever you go there you are!



I feel better with the opportunity to untangle some of these thoughts. writing this out for more public-facing consumption does encourage me towards clarity, rather than just purging everything through journaling, but maybe not necessarily critically engaging what's "true." I feel like I've mined some useful reminders for moving forward, as well - (1) process, not perfection; (2) let the negative "be" without judgment (3) take some time and space for gratitude + wins.. today, I ran longer than I ever have in my entire goddamn life! and it was done almost automatically. & i'm still here, documenting my journey! just a reminder that things ARE shifting and chang; celebrating the small wins will light the way.
